articles.headline: Union Loss May Bring New Phase of Campaign Against Amazon
articles.snippet: After an election defeat in Alabama, many in labor are shifting strategies, wary of the challenges and expense of winning votes site by site.
articles.abstract: After an election defeat in Alabama, many in labor are shifting strategies, wary of the challenges and expense of winning votes site by site.
articles.lead_paragraph: The lopsided vote against a union at Amazon’s warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., was a major disappointment to organized labor, which regards the fight with Amazon as central to labor’s survival. Yet the defeat doesn’t mark the end of the campaign against Amazon so much as a shift in strategy.

articles.headline: Plunging Johnson & Johnson Vaccine Supply Dents State Inoculation Efforts
articles.snippet: With deliveries from Johnson & Johnson set to fall 86 percent, a White House official warned that the vaccine would be scarce until a troubled Baltimore plant gains regulatory approval.
articles.abstract: With deliveries from Johnson & Johnson set to fall 86 percent, a White House official warned that the vaccine would be scarce until a troubled Baltimore plant gains regulatory approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Supplies of Johnson & Johnson’s one-dose coronavirus vaccine will be extremely limited until federal regulators approve production at a Baltimore manufacturing plant with a pattern of quality-control lapses, the White House’s pandemic response coordinator said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: We Asked Congress’s Freshmen to Give Up Stock Trading. Few Were Willing.
articles.snippet: Playing individual stocks is a losing strategy more often than not, and it poses political risk. But only a handful of newly minted lawmakers saw it that way.
articles.abstract: Playing individual stocks is a losing strategy more often than not, and it poses political risk. But only a handful of newly minted lawmakers saw it that way.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s easy to forget that just a year ago, senators from both parties were under Justice Department scrutiny for potentially profiteering from the coronavirus with well-timed stock trades.

articles.headline: Inside the Fight for the Future of The Wall Street Journal
articles.snippet: A special team led by a high-level manager says Rupert Murdoch’s paper must evolve to survive. But a rivalry between editor and publisher stands in the way.
articles.abstract: A special team led by a high-level manager says Rupert Murdoch’s paper must evolve to survive. But a rivalry between editor and publisher stands in the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Could Ron DeSantis Be Trump’s G.O.P. Heir? He’s Certainly Trying.
articles.snippet: Florida’s governor has elbowed his way to the front of the line of 2024 Republican hopefuls by leveraging a brand of “competent Trumpism” (as one ally put it) and hitting back at critics of his pandemic leadership.
articles.abstract: Florida’s governor has elbowed his way to the front of the line of 2024 Republican hopefuls by leveraging a brand of “competent Trumpism” (as one ally put it) and hitting back at critics of his pandemic leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — No one had to tell Ron DeSantis that his mock debates had bordered on disastrous. His answers rambled. He seemed uninspired.

articles.headline: Why Buy a Yacht When You Can Buy a Newspaper?
articles.snippet: Billionaires aren’t usually cast as saviors of democracy. But one way they are winning plaudits for civic-minded endeavors is by funding the Fourth Estate.
articles.abstract: Billionaires aren’t usually cast as saviors of democracy. But one way they are winning plaudits for civic-minded endeavors is by funding the Fourth Estate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Billionaires have had a pretty good pandemic. There are more of them than there were a year ago, even as the crisis has exacerbated inequality. But scrutiny has followed these ballooning fortunes. Policymakers are debating new taxes on corporations and wealthy individuals. Even their philanthropy has come under increasing criticism as an exercise of power as much as generosity.

articles.headline: Michigan’s Virus Cases Are Out of Control, Putting Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in a Bind
articles.snippet: Ms. Whitmer, a Democrat, locked down her state over the din of protests last year. Now she is trying a different approach, appealing to personal responsibility.
articles.abstract: Ms. Whitmer, a Democrat, locked down her state over the din of protests last year. Now she is trying a different approach, appealing to personal responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nowhere in America is the coronavirus pandemic more out of control than in Michigan.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: A Teacher Marched to the Capitol. When She Got Home, the Fight Began.
articles.snippet: Kristine Hostetter was a beloved fourth-grade teacher. Then came the pandemic, the election and the Jan. 6 riot in Washington.
articles.abstract: Kristine Hostetter was a beloved fourth-grade teacher. Then came the pandemic, the election and the Jan. 6 riot in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. — Word got around when Kristine Hostetter was spotted at a public mask-burning at the San Clemente pier, and when she appeared in a video sitting onstage as her husband spoke at a QAnon convention. People talked when she angrily accosted a family wearing masks near a local surfing spot, her granddaughter in tow.

articles.headline: Companies Can’t Stop Overworking
articles.snippet: Excess work isn’t good for anyone, employers included. So why are we still doing it?
articles.abstract: Excess work isn’t good for anyone, employers included. So why are we still doing it?
articles.lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

articles.headline: Afghan President in ‘Desperate Situation’ as His Power Is Undermined
articles.snippet: Ashraf Ghani has few remaining allies, the Taliban are gaining militarily and his international supporters are impatient with him and the stumbling peace process.
articles.abstract: Ashraf Ghani has few remaining allies, the Taliban are gaining militarily and his international supporters are impatient with him and the stumbling peace process.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — He attends international conferences, meets with diplomats, recently inaugurated a dam and delivers patriotic speeches vowing to defend his country against the Taliban.

articles.headline: Young Migrants Crowd Shelters, Posing Test for Biden
articles.snippet: The administration is under intensifying pressure to expand its capacity to care for as many as 35,000 unaccompanied minors, part of a wave of people crossing the border.
articles.abstract: The administration is under intensifying pressure to expand its capacity to care for as many as 35,000 unaccompanied minors, part of a wave of people crossing the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The desperate plea landed this week in the email inboxes of employees in government agencies like the Department of Homeland Security and NASA: Will you consider taking a four-month paid leave from your job to help care for migrant children in government-run shelters packed with new arrivals at the border?
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: My Family’s Global Vaccine Journey
articles.snippet: We were spread across three continents, at the mercy of vaccine geopolitics. Which of us would be inoculated last?
articles.abstract: We were spread across three continents, at the mercy of vaccine geopolitics. Which of us would be inoculated last?
articles.lead_paragraph: In early February, my sister posted a video in our family’s WhatsApp group.

articles.headline: Blackout Hits Iran Nuclear Site in What Appears to Be Israeli Sabotage
articles.snippet: The power failure was described by Iran as “nuclear terrorism” as talks were underway in Vienna to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
articles.abstract: The power failure was described by Iran as “nuclear terrorism” as talks were underway in Vienna to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: A power failure that appeared to have been caused by a deliberately planned explosion struck Iran’s Natanz uranium enrichment site on Sunday, in what Iranian officials called an act of sabotage that they suggested had been carried out by Israel.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Rick Gladstone and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Biden’s Infrastructure Push Spurs a Flurry of Lobbying in Congress
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in both parties are lining up to get their pet projects and policy priorities included in the expansive package.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in both parties are lining up to get their pet projects and policy priorities included in the expansive package.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress have begun a frenzy of lobbying to ensure that their pet projects and policy priorities are included in President Biden’s $2 trillion infrastructure and jobs plan, eager to shape what could be one of the most substantial public works investments in a generation.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane, Pranshu Verma and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: ‘Like the Tiger King Got Elected Tax Collector’: Inside the Case That Ensnared Matt Gaetz
articles.snippet: Joel Greenberg, a onetime local official in Florida, is accused of an array of crimes, including bribery, stalking and corruption.
articles.abstract: Joel Greenberg, a onetime local official in Florida, is accused of an array of crimes, including bribery, stalking and corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE MARY, Fla. — Long before the F.B.I. began to scrutinize a tax collector in Florida named Joel Greenberg — and long before his trail led them to Representative Matt Gaetz — he amassed an outlandish record in the mundane local public office he had turned into a personal fief of power.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei, Michael S. Schmidt and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Why We’re Freaking Out About Substack
articles.snippet: A company that makes it easy to charge for newsletters has captivated an anxious industry because it embodies larger forces and contradictions.
articles.abstract: A company that makes it easy to charge for newsletters has captivated an anxious industry because it embodies larger forces and contradictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Danny Lavery had just agreed to a two-year, $430,000 contract with the newsletter platform Substack when I met him for coffee last week in Brooklyn, and he was deciding what to do with the money.

articles.headline: Online Schools Are Here to Stay, Even After the Pandemic
articles.snippet: Some families have come to prefer stand-alone virtual schools and districts are rushing to accommodate them — though questions about remote learning persist.
articles.abstract: Some families have come to prefer stand-alone virtual schools and districts are rushing to accommodate them — though questions about remote learning persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Myanmar Coup Puts the Seal on Autocracy’s Rise in Southeast Asia
articles.snippet: Not long ago, democracy seemed to be surging in the region. But in Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and elsewhere, it is in trouble.
articles.abstract: Not long ago, democracy seemed to be surging in the region. But in Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and elsewhere, it is in trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last month, foreign officials in army regalia toasted their hosts in Naypyidaw, the bunkered capital built by Myanmar’s military. Ice clinked in frosted glasses. A lavish spread had been laid out for the foreign dignitaries in honor of Myanmar’s Armed Forces Day.

articles.headline: After Nuclear Site Blackout, Thunder From Iran, and Silence From U.S.
articles.snippet: The Americans and Israelis have worked together in the past to impede Iran’s nuclear ambitions, but the U.S. denies that was the case in the latest sabotage.
articles.abstract: The Americans and Israelis have worked together in the past to impede Iran’s nuclear ambitions, but the U.S. denies that was the case in the latest sabotage.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The last time the centrifuges crashed at Iran’s underground nuclear fuel-production center at Natanz, more than a decade ago, the sabotage was the result of a joint Israeli-American cyberattack intended to slow Tehran’s progress toward nuclear weapons and force a diplomatic negotiation.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Ant Group Announces Overhaul as China Tightens Its Grip
articles.snippet: Beijing had accused the internet-finance titan, a sister company of the e-commerce giant Alibaba, of flouting regulations in its quest for growth.
articles.abstract: Beijing had accused the internet-finance titan, a sister company of the e-commerce giant Alibaba, of flouting regulations in its quest for growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s fast-moving campaign to curb the power of internet giants has hit its latest mark: Ant Group, the fintech sister company of the e-commerce behemoth Alibaba.

articles.headline: Defying Republicans, Big Companies Keep the Focus on Voting Rights
articles.snippet: A coalition of law firms has joined business leaders in wanting to use their clout to oppose state legislation that would make it harder to vote.
articles.abstract: A coalition of law firms has joined business leaders in wanting to use their clout to oppose state legislation that would make it harder to vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Republicans in Texas and other states continuing to advance restrictive election legislation, corporate chieftains around the country have stepped up their efforts in recent days to oppose such laws and defend voting rights.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Microsoft to Buy Nuance for $16 Billion to Focus on Health Care Tech
articles.snippet: By acquiring a provider of artificial-intelligence software, the tech giant is hoping to bolster its offerings for the fast-growing field of medical computing.
articles.abstract: By acquiring a provider of artificial-intelligence software, the tech giant is hoping to bolster its offerings for the fast-growing field of medical computing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Monday that it would buy Nuance Communications, a provider of artificial-intelligence and speech-recognition software, for about $16 billion, as it pushes to expand its health care technology services.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced, Cade Metz and Karen Weise
